# Small Example

Consider that we have a set $S$ define as $$S = \{(0, 0), (1, 1)\}$$.
We can visualise $S$ in $\mathbb{R}^2$:

```{python fig.cap="Visualise of points"}
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

points = [[0, 0], [1, 1]]
x = [p[0] for p in points]
y = [p[1] for p in points]

plt.plot(
    x,
    y,
    linestyle=None,
    linewidth=0,
    marker="o",
    color="cyan"
)
```

We can classify the points in $S$
into two classes:
$C_1 = \{(0, 0)\}$
and
$C_2 = \{(1, 1)\}$.
The classification
is supported by the vector
$(1, 1)$.

```{python fig.cap="Visualise of points and classifier"}
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

points = [[0, 0]]
x = [p[0] for p in points]
y = [p[1] for p in points]

plt.plot(
    x,
    y,
    linestyle=None,
    linewidth=0,
    marker="o",
    color="green"
)

points = [[1, 1]]
x = [p[0] for p in points]
y = [p[1] for p in points]

plt.plot(
    x,
    y,
    linestyle=None,
    linewidth=0,
    marker="o",
    color="blue"
)

classifier = [[1, 0], [0, 1]]
x = [p[0] for p in classifier]
y = [p[1] for p in classifier]

plt.plot(
    x,
    y,
    color="red"
)
```


```{python fig.cap="Example"}
from sklearn import svm
X = [[0, 0], [1, 1]]
y = [0, 1]
clf = svm.SVC()
clf.fit(X, y)
```
